Inventory, Folder/Box LevelThis finding aid was produced using ArchivesSpace 2018-05-17T15:00:56Description is in EnglishDescribing Archives: A Content Standard
Tamiment Library and Robert F. Wagner Labor Archives
American Federation of State, County and Municipal Employees, Local 1930 Records
AFSCME. Local 1930 (New York, N.Y.)
AFSCME. Local 1930 (New York, N.Y.)
WAG.040
15 Linear Feet (15 boxes)
1930-1990 The New York Public Library Guild Local 1930 was chartered by the American Federation of State, County and Municipal Employees in April 1968. The Local represents employees in all branch libraries and research libraries of the New York Public Library system, and in the libraries of mayoral departments and agencies. The records consist of constitutions and by-laws, correspondence, minutes, notes, agendas, memoranda, resolutions, legal records, contract negotiations, grievance records, newspapers, publications, tapes, photographs, contact sheets, negatives and memorabilia. Materials are in English Materials stored offsite and advance notice is required for use. Please contact tamiment.wagner@nyu.edu at least two business days prior to research visit.
Scope and Contents
The records consist of constitutions and by-laws, correspondence, minutes, notes, agendas, memoranda, resolutions, legal records, contract negotiations, grievance records, newspapers, publications, tapes, photographs, contact sheets, negatives and memorabilia. The records reflect the structure and functions of Local 1930 and the Local's relationship with District Council 37, AFSCME, other library locals, and with the AFL-CIO on the state and national levels. The bulk of the material dates from the presidency of David Beasley (1968-1975).
Immediate Source of Acquisition
Donated by Local 1930 president Sally Campbell in 1979. Many of these materials were salvaged by David Beasley and local volunteers from a fire resulting from the bombing of the Local's former headquarters. The accession number associated with this gift is 1979.017. An additional donation of material was made by Local president Carol Thomas in 2008.
Historical/Biographical Note
The New York Public Library Guild Local 1930 was chartered by the American Federation of State, County and Municipal Employees in April 1968. The Local represents employees in all branch libraries and research libraries of the New York Public Library system, and in the libraries of mayoral departments and agencies. The bargaining unit includes professional, non-professional and technical titles.
Conditions Governing Access
Materials are open without restrictions, except for disciplinary and termination files located in box 12. Please contact Tamiment Library and Robert F. Wagner Archives regarding access to these materials, tamiment.wagner@nyu.edu, (212) 998-2630.
Arrangement
The collection is unprocessed.
Preferred Citation
Identification of item, date; American Federation of State, County, and Municipal Employees, Local 1930; WAG 040; box number; folder number; Tamiment Library/Robert F. Wagner Labor Archives, New York University.
Conditions Governing Use
Copyright (or related rights to publicity and privacy) for materials in this collection, created by AFSCME, Local 1930, was not transferred to New York University. Permission to use materials must be secured from the copyright holder.
Processing Information
In 2014, the archived websites were added as Series I.
Custodial History
The archived website was migrated from the California Digital Library's Web Archiving Service to the Internet Archive's Archive-It Service in November 2015. The link to California Digital Library was removed in October 2017.

Archived WebsiteJan 28, 2009-ongoing
American Federation of State, County and Municipal Employees, Local 1930: Jan 28, 2009-ongoing
Scope and Content Note
The New York Public Library Guild Local 1930, formed in 1968, represents almost 2,000 clericals, library technical assistants, information assistants, librarians, and other titles. Members of Local 1930 are employed by the New York Public Library, by the City of New York in its branch libraries, and the libraries of mayoral departments and agencies. The bargaining unit includes professional, non-professional and technical positions. As an activist union, they believe libraries are the backbone of democracy and unions are the vehicles to defend the economic rights of clerks, library technical assistants, information assistants, librarians, and others.
Physical Characteristics and Technical Requirements
Due to technical or privacy issues, archived websites may not be exact copies of the original website at the time of the web crawl. Certain file types will not be captured dependent on how they are embedded in the site. Other parts of websites that the crawler has difficulty capturing includes Javascript, streaming content, database-driven content, and highly interactive content.
